awd_titl_txt: Characterizing Potential Energy Surfaces for Hydrocarbon Activation by Transition Metal, Metal Cluster and Metal Oxide Cations via Spectroscopy and Photofragment Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program-A of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Ricardo B. Metz from the University of Massachusetts Amherst, will characterize the structure and bonding of the molecular reactants, products and, especially, reaction intermediates of the reactions of metal, metal cluster and metal oxide cations with hydrocarbons using vibrational and electronic spectroscopy in a dual time-of-flight mass spectrometer. Systems of interest include ions that convert methane to larger hydrocarbons, methane to methanol, and ethylene to benzene. These systems will be studied for several metals and as a function of cluster size, to measure periodic trends in the structure and bonding of intermediates and to correlate them to the measured size-dependent reactivities. Photofragment imaging will also be used to study ions' photodissociation dynamics following electronic excitation, measuring kinetic energy release and fragment anisotropy. This is a detailed probe of excited state dynamics and the couplings between excited electronic states and will also provide accurate bond strengths. These "half-collision" experiments complement full-collision reaction studies by directly probing the potential energy surface for the reaction and by initiating the reaction from an intermediate with well-defined energy, geometry and angular momentum.

The U.S. has large production and extensive reserves of natural gas, and it is widely used for heating and to generate electricity. However, it is not typically employed as a transportation fuel. This is because methane (natural gas is 70-90% methane) is a gas that cannot be turned into a liquid at room temperature. To use methane as a transportation fuel, it needs to be converted into a liquid. Catalysts are used to convert one chemical into another, more desirable chemical; new catalysts are needed to directly, selectively and efficiently convert methane into useful liquids such as methanol. Understanding the complex reactions involved in industrial catalysis, and improving catalysts, requires combining fundamental studies, calculations, and studies of active catalysts. Results from this study will contribute to this effort by expanding our fundamental understanding of the detailed ways in which metal atoms and metal clusters react with hydrocarbons by using spectroscopy to reveal the structure and bonding in the intermediates these reactions pass through on the way from reactants to products.

por.por_cntn:
Atoms and molecules interact not just by forming chemical bonds, but also by non-covalent interactions – electrostatic attraction and repulsion between permanently or transiently charged regions. Non-covalent interactions are extremely important in solvation, the structure and function of biomolecules, and catalysis. Our research studies non-covalent interactions between transition metal ions and small, stable molecules such as water and methane. One way in which we characterize these interactions is by measuring how strong they are – their energetics or thermodynamics. However, we primarily measure how the non-covalent interaction affects the covalent chemical bonds in the participants. These physical properties are measured using laser spectroscopy with infrared, visible and ultraviolet light.  Some highlights of these studies are given below.

 

One set of experiments examined how interaction with manganese cations affect the bonds between oxygen and hydrogen in water. This influence was quantified by measuring the frequency of the O-H stretching vibration, which decreases slightly upon interaction with the metal cation. How the sizes and orientations of the orbitals the metal’s electrons are in affect how it interacts with water was studied by using ultraviolet light to promote electrons from one type of orbital to another, and measuring how this changes the structure of the water molecule and the strength of the metal-water interaction.

 

A series of experiments looked at the interaction of transition metal cations, and metal cluster cations, with methane. Methane is a cheap, abundant hydrocarbon resource. However, it is a permanent gas, which means that it remains a gas at room temperature, even at extremely high pressures.  This makes it awkward to transport and store and precludes its use as a fuel for vehicles. Direct, efficient and selective conversion of methane to a liquid such as larger hydrocarbons or methanol has been a long-standing, and yet unrealized, goal of catalysis. In the gas phase, some transition metal cations react sequentially with methane to make larger hydrocarbons. We studied the first step in this reaction: the initial interaction of a metal cation with methane. Although the metals we studied do not react with methane, interaction with the metal substantially weakens the C-H bonds in the methane, and this bond weakening is the key first step in catalytic methane activation. The extent of this bond weakening was quantified by measuring the vibrational spectra of the cation-methane complexes and observing the extent to which the frequencies of the C-H stretching vibrations decreased due to the metal. This was done for several metals (cobalt, nickel, copper and silver) to determine how the electronic configuration of the metal affects the interaction, and for complexes with single and multiple methane molecules. In addition, how the number of metal atoms affects the interaction was investigated by studying complexes of metal cluster ions with methane. This showed that complexes of four iron atoms weaken the C-H bonds in methane more (and are thus more reactive) than complexes with two or three iron atoms.

 

In all of these studies, the experimental findings are compared to predictions of theoretical models in order to extract more information from the experiments and to assess the relative accuracy of different theoretical methods.
